dt: {bc}made, done, or altered with intent to deceive: such as

dt.t: Unsuspecting users click on this {wi}faked{/wi} site instead of the real site.

dt: {bc}simulated in order to deceive an opponent

dt.t: His first outside shot, however, was blocked, but he came back with a {wi}faked{/wi} shot and then a sweet bounce pass to O'Sullivan for a layup.

shortdef: made, done, or altered with intent to deceive: such as
simulated in order to deceive an opponent

dt: {bc}to alter, manipulate, or treat so as to give a spuriously {dx_def}see {dxt|spurious||2}{/dx_def} genuine appearance to {bc}{sx|doctor||}
{bc}to deceive (an opponent) in a sports contest by means of a fake {dx_def}see {dxt|fake:2||c}{/dx_def}

dt.t: whistle a few bars … and I'll {wi}fake{/wi} the rest
if you don't have the answers, {wi}fake{/wi} it

dt: {bc}to give a fake to an opponent

dt.t: The runner {it}faked{/it} left and then cut to the right.

et: originally underworld argot, of uncertain origin

The verb {it}fake{/it} perhaps first appears in print, in the form {it}faik,{/it} in 1810. In James Hardy Vaux's "A New and Comprehensive Vocabulary of the Flash Language" (vol. 2 of Hardy's {it}Memoirs,{/it} London, 1819), it receives a very general definition: "a word so variously used, that I can only illustrate it by a few examples. To fake any person or place, may signify to rob them; to fake a person, may also imply to shoot, wound, or cut; to fake a man out and out, is to kill him; a man who inflicts wounds upon, or otherwise disfigures, himself, for any sinister purpose, is said to have faked himself … to fake a screeve, is to write a letter, or other paper; to fake a screw, is to shape out a skeleton or false key, for the purpose of screwing a particular place; to fake a cly, is to pick a pocket; etc., etc., etc." (p. 170). However, Hardy also records {it}bit-faking{/it} "coining base money" and both Vaux and the earlier {it}Lexicon Balatronicum{/it} (London, 1811, a revision of Francis Grose's {it}Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue,{/it} 1785) record {it}fakement{/it} in the sense "forgery." so the sense "to simulate, counterfeit" was perhaps part of its original meaning. Much earlier is the agent noun {it}faker,{/it} defined as "maker" in a list of "Canting Terms used by Beggars, Vagabonds, Cheaters, Cripples and Bedlams." in Randle Holme's {it}The Academy of Armory{/it} (Chester, 1688) (a book about heraldry that includes a miscellany of information having nothing to do with heraldry). Along with {it}faker{/it} Holme lists {it}Ben-Fakers,{/it} "Counterfeiters of Passes and Seals" ({it}ben{/it} is defined as "good"). This expression occurs earlier as {it}ben-feaker{/it} in Thomas Dekker's pamphlet on cant, {it}O per se O. Or A new cryer of Lanthorne and candle-light{/it} (London, 1612): "Of Ben-feakers of Jybes …They who are Counterfeiters of Passeports, are called Ben-feakers , that is to say, Good-Makers." (It is possible that Holme simply copied his entries from Dekker.) The noun {it}feaker/faker{/it} implies a corresponding verb {it}feak/fake{/it} "make," for which there appears to be no certain evidence. There is {it}feague, fegue{/it} "to beat, whip" (earliest in the compound {it}bumfeage{/it}) and "to wear out, bring about the ruin of," which are colloquial—the second sense is only attested in Restoration drama—but not argot, and which have a voiced velar consonant (aside from a single occurrence of a participle {it}feakt{/it}). A suggestion dating back to Nathan Bailey's {it}An Universal Etymological English Dictionary{/it} (4th edition, 1728) is that this word is borrowed from Dutch {it}vegen{/it} "to sweep"; compare also German {it}fegen{/it} "to wipe, clean, sweep." For further discussion see Anatoly Liberman, "A fake etymology of the word fake," {it}OUPblog,{/it} August 23, 2017.
shortdef: to alter, manipulate, or treat so as to give a spuriously genuine appearance to : doctor
to deceive (an opponent) in a sports contest by means of a fake

dt: {bc}a fake in which a player simulates throwing a pass (as in football) or taking a shot (as in basketball)

shortdef: a fake in which a player simulates throwing a pass (as in football) or taking a shot (as in basketball)

dt: {bc}a fake in which a player makes an upward movement to simulate starting to take a shot

dt.t: … senior guard Natalie Ventress had the Mustangs fooled with a nice {wi}up-fake{/wi} and right-handed layup finish.

utxt.t: Leonard later bulled his way by James to the rim, {wi}up-faked{/wi} and then made a floating jumper over the Cavaliers forward.

shortdef: a fake in which a player makes an upward movement to simulate starting to take a shot
